zhou-etal-2021-assessing.title: Assessing Cognitive Linguistic Influences in the Assignment of Blame
zhou-etal-2021-assessing.author:
Zhou, Karen  and
Smith, Ana  and
Lee, Lillian
zhou-etal-2021-assessing.paperMotivationText: Lab studies in cognition and the psychology of morality have proposed some thematic and linguistic factors that influence moral reason ing.
zhou-etal-2021-assessing.paperContributionText: This paper assesses how well the findings of these studies generalize to a large corpus of user-generated ethical situations.
zhou-etal-2021-assessing.paperResultsText: Consistent with lab studies, there are statistically significant differences in usage of firstperson passive voice, as well as first-person agents and patients, between descriptions of situations that receive different blame judgments. These features also aid performance in the task of predicting the eventual collective verdicts.
zhou-etal-2021-assessing.resourcesOtherText: online forum https://reddit.com/ r/AmItheAsshole: collection of first-person descriptions of (purportedly) real-life situations, together with commentary from other users as to who is blameworthy in the situation described
